Message.Title: Back of Napkin Estimated PPS
Message.Msg: $14.17. I got this figure by adding $3.6 billion M. Dell's holding + $1 billion paid in for a controlling share of the equity. Silver Lake and MSFT et. al put in $4.5 billion for a total equity stake of $9.1 billion in cash and stock. They then borrow $15 billion in financing from their bank lenders for a total market cap of $24.1 billion. Divide that by 1.7billion shares outstanding and you get $14.17. This could vary if the price of DELL falls or increases as that changes how much equity M. Dell hast to put in, but that is a realistic estimate.

Message.Title: laarge shareholders ?
Message.Msg: Where did this "large shareholders won't be happy with less than $X per share" come from ? A bunch of guys here with 500 Dell shares hoping to make a couple thousand dollars is where. "Large shareholders" always want the stocks they own to have higher prices. Just because they want something doesn't mean they will get it. Large shareowners lose money on stocks all the time. And potential lawsuits mean nothing. If necessary, Dell can easily make the case that $12.50 per share is well more than "fair value".

Message.Title: Special Dividend
Message.Msg: Buyout price of $15 share (latest rumored target) plus a special dividend of $2+ per share (my prediction) might be enough for the unhappy holders to move the deal forward. The special committee of the BOD, under advisement from Evercore Partners, is considering a special dividend to induce acceptance of the share offer price. The special dividend approach may offer tax advantages, to the principle players, versus a higher buyout share price. Just don't think $15 alone is enough (I'd vote NO)...$17+ motivates me. CTG

Topic.Title: Deal happening this week!

Message.Msg: You may think "we are getting 15 for sure", but that doesn't make it true. There have been zero statements from Dell and, or any private equity firm about a LBO or at what price. There have been some rumors put out by people trying to bump up the stock price, but that means nothing. In fact a buyout could be for $12 to $13 per share, or not at all. You may think there is "easy money" here, but Wall street is not that stupoid. If there was anything near certainty of a pending deal at $13.50 (or higher) then the stock price would be trading at or near that price right now.

Message.Title: Dell fair value, my 2c
Message.Msg: Here's my 2c on how to value DELL: 1) the average price of most investors is probably well above $18/shr. In a case of an LBO (no exchange of shares) most investors will see no reason to accept a low ball offer which makes them take a loss, especially as the company's officials continue to tout long term prospects. 2) Current market cap is of $23bn. Take out approx $9bn of excess cash/securities, the current operating value of the company is $13bn. Taking flat earnings of $2.5bn/yr, the current Dell market cap basically puts Dell trading at 5-6x earnings. In my opinion, it would be hard to justify any valuation below 8-9x earnings, putting shares in the $14 - 18 range using low valuation metrics. 3) Today banks are hoarding cash, and investors are hungry for yield. Dell junk bonds would easily find buyers today. So the size of the deal, even in the $30bn area, is not a problem as far as financing. I don't know if a deal will happen, but clearly the downside/upside ratio is clearly favorable for the bulls. And big size deals often happen at market tops and some indications suggest we could be at such a top. So with all the investor optimism going around, the current timing apprears to be good to announce a deal and get the financing.
